newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Stericycle sees deal accretive.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Stericycle sees deal accretive.

text.p: Stericycle Inc expects its acquisition of most of the medical waste business of WMX Technologies Inc to add to earnings next year.
In an interview with Reuters, Stericycle Chief Executive Mark Miller said the firm does not expect to post a charge against earnings on the $11 million deal.
He also said Stericycle may make more acquisitions. "We've got several other candidates we're taking a look at," he said.
Taken public in August in an initial offering that raised more than $25 million, Deerfield, Ill.-based Stericycle specializes in regulated medical waste management services.
Shares in Stericycle were up 1-1/2 to 9-1/4 in afternoon trading Monday, while WMX shares were up 3/4 to 34-1/8.
Stericycle said it paid WMX about $5.5 million cash and delivered a note for about $5.5 million.
"This acquisition significantly strengthens Stericycle's position as the second-largest provider of regulated medical waste management services," the company said.
It said its proprietary electro-thermal deactivation process destroys human pathogens without producing harmful airborne emissions, and permits resource recovery.
Stericycle said, "This acquisition represents an important step in executing the company's strategy of aggressively participating in the consolidation of the medical waste services industry."
Besides Stericycle and Waste Management, the operating arm of WMX, the other major player in the medical waste business is Browning-Ferris Industries Inc, Miller said.
